metadata.case_name: Municipal Committee of Amravati & Ors. v. Respondents

facts.text: Municipal Committee of Amravati established under C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922.

Chapter IX of the Act deals with imposition, assessment and collection of taxes; Section 66 specifies 15 varieties of taxes including clause (o) for terminal tax on goods or animals imported/exported, provided not simultaneous with octroi.

Section 66(2) empowers State Government to regulate imposition and maximum rates; (3) first imposition subject to State sanction; (4) Committee may abolish or vary taxes subject to Government control.
Section 67 lays down procedure for imposition: special meeting resolution, publish notice, State Government sanction.
Section 68 procedure for variation or abolition of taxes, including publication for increases and objections.
Terminal tax on goods imported by road or rail imposed by notification dated August 10, 1916, exempting silver, bullion and coin.
Notification superseded by June 2, 1921, confining tax to goods by rail; amended from time to time, no change after 1936.
Under Government of India Act, 1935, terminal taxes on goods by rail assigned to Centre (Item 58 List I), but pre-1937 levies continued by s.143.

Notification December 1, 1959 added silver/silver jewellery, gold/gold jewellery, precious stones to terminal tax list, by rail and road, at same rates as others; procedure under s.67 followed, Government sanctioned.
1st respondent in C.A. 598/62 carries business in gold, silver, precious stones within Amravati; challenged 1959 notification under Art.226.
High Court of Bombay at Nagpur (judgment March 18, 1961) allowed petition by majority, granted certificate.
In C.A. 695/62, notification December 9, 1960 under ss.67(5),(7) imposed terminal tax on gunpowder by rail; no prior tax on gunpowder.
Madhya Pradesh High Court judgments: October 12, 1961 (Misc. Pet. 122/61), March 18, 1961 (Misc. Pet. 319/60).
In C.A. 700/62, original notification March 17, 1926 (operative April 1, 1926); amended September 23, 1960 adding new articles and increasing rates on existing items.
Pre-1937, no tax on goods by road; 1959/1960 notifications extended to road.

legal_issues.text: Construction of Art. 277 of the Constitution and validity of terminal taxes imposed post-Constitution on new items (silver, gold, precious stones, gunpowder) and extension to road transport.
Whether Art. 277 saves post-Constitution impositions of new items or increases in rates under pre-existing terminal tax powers.

petitioner_arguments.text: Terminal tax was being lawfully levied pre-Constitution (without reference to specific articles or rates), so adding new items or increasing rates is saved by Art. 277 as same category of tax.
'Levy' includes imposition, assessment and collection, so expanding to new items is continuation.
Sufficient that Act vested power to levy terminal tax pre-Constitution (Attorney-General).

respondent_arguments.text: Post-Constitution imposition on new items (not levied pre-Constitution) not saved by Art. 277; legislative incompetency as terminal taxes under Entry 89 Union List.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 277 saves only taxes actually being lawfully levied pre-Constitution; does not permit new impositions, new items, rate increases or extensions (e.g., to road).
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Levy' means actual imposition and collection, not mere power; identity of tax, body, area, purposes, rate must continue unchanged.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects broad construction allowing category expansion; Art. 277 prevents financial dislocation but not expansion of taxation range.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Limited legislative power to continue, discontinue or reduce rates, but not enhance or add items.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Rama Krishna Ramanath v. Janpad Sabha: s.143 GIA 1935 (identical to Art.277) does not confer plenary power; tests: same tax, body, area, purposes, no enhancement.
Agrees with Chuttilal v. Bagmal: levy linked to application of proceeds, implying actual collection pre-Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proceeds if no actual levy pre-Constitution.

holdings.text: Post-Constitution notifications imposing terminal tax on new items (silver/gold etc., gunpowder) and increases/extensions invalid; not saved by Art. 277.
Art. 277 permits only exact continuance of pre-Constitution levies; no new items, no rate hikes, no new modes (road).

precedents_cited.case_name: Rama Krishna Ramanath v. The Janpad Sabha, Gondia
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of s.143(2) GIA 1935 identical to Art.277; rejects plenary power, limits to continuance without enhancement; sets tests for identity of tax.
Link between levy and application of proceeds aids narrow construction of 'levied' in Art.277.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.277 saves pre-Constitution levies; Entry 89 assigns terminal taxes to Union post-Constitution.

statutes_cited.name: C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers municipalities to impose terminal tax per procedure; notifications under ss.67,68 challenged.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Precedent for Art.277; continued pre-1937 levies; assigned rail terminal taxes to Centre.

outcome.summary: All three appeals dismissed; High Court judgments upheld quashing post-Constitution notifications adding new items to terminal tax, increasing rates, or extending to road as invalid under Art.277.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ petitions allowed by High Courts upheld; taxes on new items quashed.

key_quotes.text: "The tax must be one which was lawfully levied by a local authority for the purpose of a local area, the identity of the body that collects the tax, the area for whose benefit the tax is to be utilised and the purposes for which the utilization is to take place continue to be the same, and the rate of the tax is not enhanced nor its incidence in any manner altered, so that it continues to be the same tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Art. 277 "cannot be construed as one conferring a plenary power to legislate on those topics till such time as the Central Legislature intervened."
key_quotes.speaker: court
